description: a(n) = the smallest number m such that there are exactly n sets of consecutive primes, each of which has an arithmetic mean of m.
comments: First appearance of n in A122821.
example: a(4) = 38 because there are exactly four sets of consecutive primes which have meansof 38: {31,37,41,43}, {29,...,47}, {23,...,53} and {2,...,83},
prog: (PARI) {a(n)= m=2; starting_index=1; k=starting_index; sum_of_primes=0; prime_count=0; sets=0; until( (prime(starting_index)>m) && (sets==n), if( (prime(starting_index)> m) || (sets>n), m++; sets=0; starting_index=1; k=starting_index); sum_of_primes=sum_of_primes+prime(k); prime_count++; mean=sum_of_primes/ prime_count; if(mean<m, k++, sum_of_primes=0; prime_count=0; starting_index++; k=starting_index; if(mean==m, sets++))); return(m)} (from _Rick L. Shepherd_, Jun 14 2004)
author: _Naohiro Nomoto_, May 08 2003
